conclusion: Determine speed at t=60s using acceleration-displacement graph.
Graph shows acceleration as a function of time.
Positive acceleration indicates upward motion; negative indicates downward.
Integrate acceleration over time to find velocity.
Integral of acceleration gives change in velocity; initial velocity v0=0.
Identify time segments with different accelerations.
Calculate velocity from 0 to 1 second: v1 = 2 m/s.
Calculate velocity from 1 to 4 seconds: v2 = 8 m/s.
Calculate velocity from 4 to 5 seconds: v3 = 6 m/s.
Calculate velocity from 5 to 55 seconds: v4 = 6 m/s.
Calculate velocity from 55 to 56 seconds: v5 = 8 m/s.
Calculate velocity from 56 to 59 seconds: v6 = 8 m/s.
Calculate velocity from 59 to 60 seconds: v7 = 10 m/s.
Final velocity at t=60 seconds is 10 m/s.
